top_comment.text:
SATURDAY SHORT FILM (PROXiMITY)
My dear friends, sisters and brothers..... Saturday is a relaxing day for 
us mostly..... So I like to share this interesting short film for your 
weekend and spend it in a different way......

Today's short film is called "PROXiMITY" It's full of action, mysteries and 
some disturbing moments also (If you are so sensitive please be careful 
about that), but it shows the way of our thinking according to the system 
in our lives. I think if situation is not good sometimes, we need to think 
out of the box (system) too. It's only 11 minutes and 03 seconds long, so 
when you feel free please watch it...... and share your thoughts about 
it....
PROXiMITY (A Short Film by Ryan Connolly)

Special thanks to Ryan Connolly & Film Riot....

I hope you enjoy this short film in different way and have a great weekend 
to you all.....

Aayubowan ! (live long life)﻿

comments.author: Robert Ober

comments.text:
+Robert Ober Just because it may be popular or common doesn't mean it's 
cool to hate it. There's literally nothing wrong with it, it suits the 
style of the film and gives it a dead "gritty" look which is what the film 
was going for. If it was oversaturated you'd have armchair filmmakers 
critiquing the fact that over-saturation doesn't fit the theme of the film, 
etc. Being annoyed by it reeks of you being hipster.

comments.text:
Yep,   Shaky cam became popular after used on Homicide: Life on the Street 
starting in 1993.  I think it's time to move on.  Also,  the "hasn't been 
color corrected or graded" look is annoying and not cinematic.  Ryan is a 
good filmmaker and does not need to jump on any current bandwagon (trend).  

And yes,  this idea has been done before, including the proximity devices.

Thanks Ryan for what you do for the community.
Robert A. Ober

Ryan Connolly knows how long to make the awesome.  He just makes the films 
the length they need to be to create an internal creative spark in the 
viewer, who is then allowed to fill in the remaining story themselves.

internalize and extrapolate your own fiction from.  He's creating an 
interactive visual novel in the sense that your imagination fills in the 
story.  (I could be wrong; this is the only Ryan Connolly I've seen)

comments.text:
It's not a monetization thing though. YouTube videos really don't make 
money unless the video hits millions. It's just making sure all the views

give you a place to send the subs.
comments.author: Film Riot

comments.text:
+Film Riot
Thanks. I totally got you. As already said, I'm not here for the money, 
absolutely none of the videos on my channel are monetized. The rightfull 
owners have the ability to monetize them directly on my channel if they 
want to. I'm only providing the subtitles. And you are right, I did not 
take the time to link back to your channel and this is my bad. Please let 
me know where I can send you the subtitles if you want to feature them 
here. Best regards,
comments.author: subtitled trailers

comments.text:
I've submitted a retraction of the claim. Hope you can understand our 
position on protecting our work. View count is the main way we will be able 
to do bigger and better things. Unapproved re-uploads really do damage to 
that. Especially when they do not link back to the original film or any of 
our sites as yours didn't.
comments.author: Film Riot

comments.text:
+Film Riot Thanks a lot for your reply. It was indeed a re-upload I've made 
only to make this video available to hearing impaired people since there 
was no way to contact you directly to give you the subtitles. I've made 
only 200 views on it and I've never monetized it so you can monetize the 
video yourself directly on my channel without losing any money. However, I 
understand you want me to remove it, and I'll do it as soon as you let me 
do it. I've also made the French subtitles and I will send you them too so 
you can feature them here with the English ones. I just need you to unflag 
me to remove the video myself or my channel will be closed and it will be a 
really bad blow for all the hearing impaired community following trailers 
and short movies on this channel. Again, thank you very much for your time 
and understanding.
comments.author: subtitled trailers

comments.text:
We have a team that goes through YouTube to handle that. I have not seen 
your video, but will look into it. If it was a re-upload of our film, it 
will get tagged, as that takes views away from our film and in-turn hurts 
future productions. Being as small as we are, every view counts.

top_comment.text:
My only problem with this film is that we're not really given any reason to 
care. Beyond how tense it was (and the atmosphere was really well done), 
there's no information about who these people are. Are they convicts? Then 
this seems like a really inconvenient way to deal with them. Maybe it's 
some shadowy paramilitary group? Then why wait until all but one are dead? 
Plus, that means your numbers never actually grow. And if they are, why 
don't we ever see them? A little insight into their plans would have made 
the ending make a whole lot more sense, but presently I found it a bit 
weak.﻿

Violent yes - his genre is horror/thriller but no gore, which I like. This 
was a run and gun project that had five days each for scriptwriting and 
filming. The idea behind Film Riot is that they are learning and they share 
 what they learn with us while they do their thing, which is make films. 
Each episode has hilarious skits and, let's face it, gross stuff - boys 
will be boys - and then they take you through the effects and how to do it 
yourself. I'm a fan not only for the show but they have really helped 
 newbie filmmakers get experience  with their film challenges and have 
given short films exposure with their recommendations.

 Wow, hows that for a write-up… maybe I should get paid for this :D

top_comment.author: David Mash

comments.text:
Smelled like Wedlock (1991). But I miss a bit more reasoning for the whole 
hunting thing. I mean, why would these guards, or their owners have not 
just shot these prisoners? Why this game?

I would also loved to see a bit more personality in the main antagonist, 
perhaps some internal conflict, a tiredness, or some enjoyment of 
exercising power over others.

I liked the camera work, accept some of the macro top down handycam like 
viewpoint angles in the mud fight scene. Here some intimate narrow angle Go 
pro may have pulled the viewer into mud themselves. Also you may have 
choosen a low angle when the antagonist is leading, to make the viewer feel 
like the underdog.

Plot twist tiredness.
Ryan you're getting a bit predictable by having some bigger plot twist at 
the end of your work. My problem with such things is when they are 
illogical and or are  totally unpredictable. This film's plot twist felt to 
me did not add fun or satisfaction. If you had your antagonist hint the 
viewer of for instance trouble of conscious, hesitating to do his killing 
job, then the plot twist would have made sense, and would be rewarding for 
the viewer.

I hope you find my critique constructive and helpful.
comments.author: ookiemand

comments.text:
!***spoiler***!
I think he 'broke the cycle'. I think it's a game where the victim who 
survives becomes the hunter. so this protagonist survives, then I think he 
gets promoted to become a 'hunter' but instead of playing the game, he 
turns on the other hunter and kills him, thus breaking the vicious cycle.

comments.author: Film Riot

comments.text:
+Film Riot You know what your probably right film riot, though 80% of my 
comment was  positive  and a compliment .However with the last part being 
negative. perhaps I should have been more constructive with what I didn't 
find too great about the films story. 

That being the case, I'd rather not write a review in the comments about 
why the premise itself didn't appeal to me. As I said before everything 
else was great. No one can argue with the quality of the film production. 
(yes I realize that story is part of the production ) You guys know your 
good at this. 

 I personally thought the premise was lacking in having a point. I've read 
books and seen movies where people are hunted. That part is golden, But 
there was just this emptiness present. A lack of depth. I think if you guys 
would have given just the slightest meaning to the madness it would have 
been much better. I feel that to much was left to interpretation and that 
the after taste is vague. I think just one little hint to a greater picture 
in the world you created would have been a great boon. I think just a few 
seconds to tie some loose ends together even if it ended up raising more 
question would have been better. I'm not saying to hold the audiences hand, 
but just a little something. 

Don't take me too serious though, i over analyze. And this is just my 
opinion.
 I do however apologize for being callousness , the part was rude of me. 
I'll edit my first comment In light of my current reflection. Keep making 
movie magic.
comments.author: MrJherime

top_comment.text:
Excellent film, great photography acting and music, but i must say I still 
prefer Tell. Heres why. Your film lacked any ambiguity, specifically at 
then end. (spoilers) Instead of showing us exactly what happened at the end 
(ie the prisoner shoots the guard), it may have been more effective not 
showing who survived the end encounter. So then the truck arrives as a 
guard walks towards it (without showing his face). Arris (dressed as the 
guard) jumps off the truck and greets the other (who's face we still dont 
see). They both pull off the new prisoners all the while the focus is on 
Arris' face (literally). The other guard pulls off the hoods and the men 
run off. Suddenly the other guard raises his rifle and spins round to Arris 
pulling the trigger. Todd Bruno's character survived. He then runs to the 
drivers side and hijacks the truck, making his escape. The end. (I dont 
think its a better ending but its food for thought). Love your work guys 
and hope that "Outsiders" happens!﻿

Considering the type of thing you've put out in the past, this is kind of a 
disappointment for me, sorry guys. The story had little to no weight for 
me, I never felt involved in what was going on, or had any reason to root 
for anyone. I assume it was meant to be mysterious, but it came off as just 
a bunch of pointless violence. It definitely would've helped to have some 
more context. The visuals did nothing for me either, drab and colorless. 
I'm normally completely on board for the whole washed out desaturated look, 
but it's not working for me here. Also, what's with the ww1 era rifles, 
felt very out of place. The acting was cool, and I can definitely 
appreciate how rough this must've been on the actors. 

If this was some other channel, I wouldn't care. But I love your work, the 
skits, losses and tell were both fantastic, so this is kind of a let down. 
This is only my opinion in the end, however objective I try to be, I hope 
you don't take my words as mindless hate.﻿

All the first comments were just stylistic differences of opinion, so I 
wont comment there. But The lead stopped running because the shot startled 
him. He knew they had guns but he was in disbelief that they actually just 
executed a wounded unarmed man. He was also trying to gauge how far they 
were and from what distance so he could make his next move - (Since in the 
forest you easily get turned around and lose your sense of direction). 
That's why he waited for the second shot.

top_comment.text:
My Thoughts:
Fantastic job at mimicking the film look. 
Anamorphic lens looked wonderful. Lens flares where subtle and pleasant. 
The filter or color correction, in my opinion, was slightly to contrasty, 
shadows were harsh, although that could have been for styalistic purposes.
Dialogue was pretty good, with an impressive performance from the main 
character. Your friends could use some work ;). 
Fight scene looked impressive!
Cinematography and editing were relatively seamless.
Sound was great!
The film was scored excellently! Who did it?

As far as story, a few constructive things *SPOILERS*:
Why where the first two connected separately from the other two? Is it 
supposed to be because, ideally, the two "bound" together would work 
together to win? If so, who is the man with the main character once he had 
become a hunter? Why did the  main character kill him? I imagine, based on 
story, that he is in the same position as our main character? Although I 
did notice that he was wearing a hat, just as the older, more square 
looking man who our main character shot in the neck prior.

The stick in the ribs didn't even phase main characters physical 
capabilities.
You should have had a bloodier mess when he smashed the guys leg off to get 
his brace. I'm talkin' blood splattering on his face.
Why would the main character, who now just acquired the other man's brace, 
run TOWARD a man with a rifle instead of trying to escape? Why did no ones 
face ever bleed from repeated punches? Did the main character get lucky 
from the neck shot he fired from his hip, while he was on his back or is he 
trained? The guy with the sides of his head saved had a visible 2 on his 
ankle in the beginning but a much larger "2xx" number when the main 
character checks it later in the film. Why was this significant? The 
numbers are whats confusing me. I feel they most obviously allude to the 
number of times they have done this or killed someone? But why did the main 
character have such a high number as well?  It makes me think of thousands 
of questions trying to rationalize its context to the story. All of which 
lead to many more questions trying to rationalize a back story that doesn't 
necessarily make sense with the situation you placed us in.

Critically,

I feel with the effert that seemed to be expended on realism, somethings 
were just, well, relatively unrealistic.

Overall though,

Excellent independent production!

Huge congratulations, and best of luck in the future!

Ryan,
You express your best skill as a DP.﻿
top_comment.author: Conpwn

comments.text:
Thanks for the compliment! And I appreciate your criticisms - they're good 
and constructive. There are some plot points that we simply didn't have 
time to flesh out in a 10 minute film, but I may be able to clear up some 
of your questions: 

The numbers on the ankles are identification, in numerical order according 
to when the candidates entered the program. The fact that the Hunter's 
number is "244" and Jake's number is "246" tells him that the Hunter was 
initiated just before Jake was. 

If a Prisoner survives, they move to the next level and become a Hunter in 
the next round...

When Jake runs TOWARD the Hunter instead of away, it indicates that he's 
through running. He's going to take the fight to the Hunter and end this 
for good, one way or the other...

Hope this helps clear it up a little!
comments.author: Todd Bruno

comments.text:
+gymhockey2587 A good short film, like a feature film, has a fully 
completed story arc. You just have to be more creative to be able to pull 
it off in less time. I feel like this short film was more of "look at what 
I can do with all this nice equipment" from a talented DP rather than using 
the medium of cinema to best convey a great story.

Just my opinion.

Still, a great independent production!
comments.author: Conpwn

comments.text:
All of your criticisms about the story are right.  There is a lot left 
unanswered.  However, you do have to keep in mind that this is a short 
film, and a ten minute one at that.  Those kind of details are something I 
would expect a feature film to address, but being that this is a ten minute 
short those things are less important.

Very good critique however, a lot of constructive criticism!

To answer your first question in my opinion:
1. They were in shock. People don't respond properly to things when they 
are in shock. 2. They didn't know how the shackles worked, maybe the 
shackles would explode if one of them died. He only found out after he 
accidentally killed the other guy. 3. Not everyone is prepared to be a 
murderer, some of us prefer teamwork before resorting to something selfish.

To answer the 2nd question:
Obviously theres some organization behind the game and the rules are that 
you become the guard after you've survived. To me little details like that 
aren't that important for a short film like this.

Subtitle:
www.subtitledtrailers.com

- Take it easy.
- Who the hell are you?

- Stay where you are!
- What did you do to me?

These things, on our legs,
are connected.
Stay away from me!
Okay.
Listen.
Look at me!
See these clothes?

You see what I'm wearing.
This is one ugly shirt, right?

You couldn't pay me to wear these.
I'm not exactly a khakis kind of guy.
These are not my clothes.

But that doesn't actually concern me.
You know what does?
That we match.
We're in the same boat, man.
We're in the same ugly-ass clothes.
You see that shackle on your leg?

I've got one too.
And they seems to start

to freak out if they get
too far apart from each other, so...

I personally think,
it's in our best interest
to stay in this boat together.

What do you think?
You agree?
Yeah.
Good.

Now, I think whoever brought us here
expected us to split up.

So now
that we've broken their cycle,
What do you say we...
Shit!
Hey!
Come on, calm down!

title: PROXiMITY (A Short Film by Ryan Connolly)
